{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2981176,"name":"RedLeader342","username":"RedLeader342","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/redleader342/{size}/174347_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-11T22:11:19.796Z","cooked":"

Hey everyone. This may seem like a silly question but I didn’t find the answer in other topics.
Every year we have used a solid belly pan from Lexan or something. Well this year we are getting a cnc router and figured why not do a stronger pan from sheet metal and have it pocketed with a diamond pattern like some other teams do. However a concern was raised of “what about stuff from the floor getting into the electronics? like carpet fuzz or various debris?”
So I came here to ask if any of you have had issue with this before? I assume with the great number of successful teams who use similar designs that this isn’t an issue, but figured I also don’t know for sure so why not ask. Thanks!

And certainly not Burn-E."},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/1","custom_user_title":"Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2981179,"name":"Andrew Lawrence","username":"Andrew_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_l/{size}/270442_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-11T22:24:39.736Z","cooked":"
RedLeader342:

why not do a stronger pan from sheet metal and have it pocketed with a diamond pattern like some other teams do

Because it takes an insane amount of time and effort, provides minimal benefit, and is going to be a huge resource-drain that would better be applied to other aspects of your robot.

I also prefer 6mm / 1/4" plywood to polycarb. It’s cheap, easy to use, rigid, and is gonna do just as sufficient a job as a pocketed aluminum bellypan.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-11T22:24:39.736Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":496,"readers_count":495,"score":334.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"Andrew Lawrence","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28413,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Yo! Champ in the making!"},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/2","custom_user_title":"Yo! Champ in the making!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":11}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981180,"name":"RedLeader342","username":"RedLeader342","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/redleader342/{size}/174347_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-11T22:29:08.292Z","cooked":"

to be fair i did title this questions as in multiple.
but really i only had one question i was looking to have answered and that was about debris getting into electronics.
it really doesnt take much time of effort now a days with laser cutters and water jets and cnc routers and such.
likely we’ll slap lexan on early in the season for something quick and easy to use, then as we get farther into planning, we’ll design a proper pan with specific spots for electronics and such and knock it out on the cnc router

I’d say probably most uplifted debris would be near wheels. Most of our electronics are protected from debris given most swarf comes from above from people working on the robot. Just meaning electrical tape over unused RoboRIO ports, etc.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-11T23:07:22.175Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":467,"readers_count":466,"score":128.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981188,"name":"Troy Dietz","username":"troy_dietz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/troy_dietz/{size}/135768_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-12T00:21:57.159Z","cooked":"
RedLeader342:

However a concern was raised of “what about stuff from the floor getting into the electronics? like carpet fuzz or various debris?”

Yes, it does do that. It has also never mattered in my experience.
Carpet debris causing problems will be long strings and tape getting pulled up into chains/belts. The fluff (and wheel material) dust is nasty, but won’t cause any issues unless you have an IR sensor or camera down by your drive wheels for some reason.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-12T00:21:57.159Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":440,"readers_count":439,"score":133.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/5","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981191,"name":"Monochron","username":"Monochron","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/monochron/{size}/2728_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-12T00:41:27.063Z","cooked":"
RedLeader342:

it really doesnt take much time of effort now a days with laser cutters and water jets and cnc routers and such.

You mentioned that you don’t have the router yet, how are you sure of the time requirements? If you have access to a water jet or laser that can cut aluminum, that might be somewhat quick. But even learning to use your router this close to build season is going to eat into your build time. The setup for cutting stock is tine consuming and, depending on what machine you get, a full belly pan could be a lot of time to cut. It’s doable, yes. But there are so many better things you can spend your time on in your first year with the tool.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-12T18:09:29.873Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":427,"readers_count":426,"score":250.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"Monochron","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981205,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-12T02:03:53.972Z","cooked":"

For the last few years, our team has been using 1/4" recycled HDPE sheet for our belly pans. We do shape the sheet on the CnC router (an Omio X8) to fit the frame, mechanisms, etc. and to put some holes and slots into it for specific purposes, but no pocketing. That means machining the plate is pretty quick. We did one engraved with our team number and with multiple wire-fastener slots for our swerve testbed robot in about 30 minutes. This HDPE makes for a strong, slick-surfaced slightly flexible bottom for the robot. Minimizes problems with field elements, game pieces (looking at you, power cells) and anything that might get caught on your underside (like another robot.) Works easily with most tools, machines cleanly, handles standard hardware (bolts, rivits, etc.) just fine, tough, strong; hard to ask for more than that.

Yeah, its weight too, so just don’t be putting nuttin’ down there in harms way!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-12T13:06:08.368Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":351,"readers_count":350,"score":80.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"Sam Geckler","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":14572,"username":"Nick_Coussens","name":"Nick Coussens","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nick_coussens/{size}/231882_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21515,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981289,"name":"Einav Bar-Nir","username":"Enavbn","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/enavbn/{size}/197603_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-12T17:39:33.131Z","cooked":"
RedLeader342:

what about stuff from the floor getting into the electronics?

We’ve been using this type of belly pan for the past few seasons and never had a problem. (Note: manufactured by a sponsor, not in-house)

We make sure that the screws we use to connect the electronics in the belly pan are either with rounded heads or countersunk (with their heads towards the floor), so they don’t get caught on anything on the floor. We also make sure zip ties are properly cut. Debris doesn’t really have a way to enter the panel as most of the triangles are blocked with components or cables.

To protect the electronics even more on top, we have a panel of polycarbonate with dual lock that can be easily removed if we need access. We had another small piece of polycarbonate in between our two belly pans to stop cables from dropping to the floor and minimize damage to them from any debris.

image1207×2098 570 KB
image3840×2160 2.4 MB

If you meant a belly pan that all components are faced towards the floor - we never tried it but teams that we saw did usually covered over the components with a polycarbonate sheets to protect them.

","username":"IndySam","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/indysam/{size}/111341_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-12T17:47:58.253Z","cooked":"

I am also in the plywood camp but if you want to do a cool metal belly pan with cutouts and are worried about stuff getting inside just use very thin polycarb on the inside. It will weigh very little and still give you that cool look.

well we do also have access to laser and water jet through our sponsor. but we figure we’ll give this a try first and if it doesn’t work out well enough or fast enough we’ll send it off.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-12T18:02:39.065Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":70.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"RedLeader342","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":8115,"username":"Monochron","name":"Monochron","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/monochron/{size}/2728_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14252,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E."},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/12","custom_user_title":"Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981396,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T04:51:51.270Z","cooked":"

We’ve put our belly pan on the top rail and faced it down 3 or 4 times. A skin of 1/16 polycarbonate on the bottom protects it, and having full access to your electronics is fantastic.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-13T04:51:51.270Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":315,"readers_count":314,"score":103.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":14572,"username":"Nick_Coussens","name":"Nick Coussens","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nick_coussens/{size}/231882_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/13","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981407,"name":"Yousuf","username":"the.juc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/the.juc/{size}/161467_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T08:14:57.239Z","cooked":"

We typically find a way to vertically mount our electronics and cover them with a lexan shield that has a hinge or is removable with velcro. This typically makes them more accessible for maintenance. There’s an example below that the ArmyAnts did in 2020. You could still put electronics on the bottom and protect them with lexan. One year we even mounted electronics on the underside of the bellypan and covered them with lexan…don’t recommend that one lol.

2020 Army Ants Robot_RECOVERED_2 53840×2160 1.13 MB

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-13T08:16:22.033Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":303,"readers_count":302,"score":160.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"Yousuf","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/b/5/b553c86452a699d9e454cf263a347770cd590f5f.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50042,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ZouKeepers"},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/14","custom_user_title":"ZouKeepers","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981419,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T13:37:04.203Z","cooked":"

The control system components can be installed on the inside surface of the vertical panels so they are naturally protected without needing extra panels. Just make sure there is sufficient clearance from components and mechanisms that move.

A variation of this is to attach the control system to one or more subpanels, wire and test them for proper function outside of the robot then attach the subpanels using appropriate quantities of Dual Lock. This construction method allows the construction and testing of the control system to occur in parallel with the construction of the robot chassis and mechanisms.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":33,"updated_at":"2021-12-13T13:37:04.203Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":294,"readers_count":293,"score":88.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398052,"topic_slug":"some-belly-pan-question","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":50042,"username":"the.juc","name":"Yousuf","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/the.juc/{size}/161467_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/some-belly-pan-question/398052/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2981424,"name":"John Keyzer","username":"John_Keyzer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john_keyzer/{size}/163246_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-13T14:49:49.636Z","cooked":"

As others have stated, I would not be overly concerned with things being picked up off of the floor. My larger concern would be that you not base anything critical on a new machine/ technology until you are sure you have sufficient experience/ expertise with said equipment. We are in a unique position moving forward, we have a new lab this year that will include an Omax waterjet (ProtoMax) Haas VF2SS 5 Axis, Boss Accu-Cut 1kw fiber laser and 33ton cnc press brake. As much as it pains me, we will not be using any of them, because final hookup and startup will not be completed until after kickoff, and we will not be proficient with them yet.

the.juc:

One year we even mounted electronics on the underside of the bellypan and covered them with lexan…don’t recommend that one lol.

Why not? We’ve been doing the underside electronics with excellent results for three years. It’s a damn sight better than digging hands under a superstructure to replace a component or connector. 100% would recommend!

It was pretty cumbersome to flip our robot every time—especially bc we had a lot of electronics issues that year. Also it feels a little risky if there’s any kind of rough terrain on the field. I will say it is definitely better than having to reach through a bunch of stuff. My team has just developed a liking for a dedicated electronics panel mounted vertically.
